Handling Receiver Functions¶

Supposing that you have created receiver functions and have them available in the directory output/RF, we can now start imaging!

Handling of receiver functions is generally done by using the RFTrace and RFStream classes. These classes are built upon a modified version of the rf project by Tom Eulenfeld.

Note

Just as in the obspy base classes, an RFStream can hold several receiver functions, while an RFTrace object can only hold one receiver function. As all rfs are saved in .sac format, saving RFStream will lead to the creation of several files.

Receiver functions in .sac format can be read using the read_rf() function. By doing so, we obtain an RFStream object, on which we can apply a number of functions.

Methods available for both RFStream and RFTrace objects¶

  • write()

    to write receiver function(s) to SAC file(s) (in time domain).

  • moveout()

    to migrate the receiver function(s) to depth domain using one of the provided depth models (either ‘3D’ for GyPsum or ‘iasp91.dat’ for iasp91). Piercing points will be appended to the object.

  • ppoint()

    to compute the piercing points in depth without migrating the receiver function

  • plot()

    to plot the receiver function(s). The plot will be different depending on the type of receiver function: 1. For depth-migrated RFs, the plot will be against depth. 2. For an RFTrace in time domain, the plot will be against time. 3. For an RFStream in time domain, the plot will show the receiver functions depending on epicentral distance.

Methods for RFStream objects¶

  • station_stack()

    to create a station specific stack of all receiver function in the object. For that to work, all RFs, have to be from the same station.
